title: Montgomery, Alabama
text:
Montgomery is the <a href="capital%20city">capital city</a> of the <a href="U.S.%20state">U.S. state</a> of <a href="Alabama">Alabama</a> and the <a href="county%20seat">county seat</a> of <a href="Montgomery%20County%2C%20Alabama">Montgomery County</a>. Named for <a href="Richard%20Montgomery">Richard Montgomery</a>, it stands beside the <a href="Alabama%20River">Alabama River</a>, on the <a href="Gulf%20Coastal%20Plain">coastal Plain of the Gulf of Mexico</a>. In the <a href="2020%20United%20States%20census">2020 Census</a>, Montgomery's population was 200,603. It is the third most populous city in Alabama, after <a href="Birmingham%2C%20Alabama">Birmingham</a> and <a href="Huntsville%2C%20Alabama">Huntsville</a>, and is the <a href="List%20of%20United%20States%20cities%20by%20population">119th most populous</a> in the United States. The <a href="Montgomery%20Metropolitan%20Area">Montgomery Metropolitan Statistical Area</a>'s population in 2020 was 386,047; it is the fourth largest in the state and 142nd among <a href="List%20of%20metropolitan%20statistical%20areas">United States metropolitan area</a>s.
The city was incorporated in 1819 as a merger of two towns situated along the <a href="Alabama%20River">Alabama River</a>. It became the state capital in 1846, representing the shift of power to the south-central area of Alabama with the growth of cotton as a commodity crop of the <a href="Black%20Belt%20%28geological%20formation%29">Black Belt</a> and the rise of <a href="Mobile%2C%20Alabama">Mobile</a> as a mercantile port on the Gulf Coast. In February 1861, Montgomery was chosen the first capital of the <a href="Confederate%20States%20of%20America">Confederate States of America</a>, which it remained until the Confederate seat of government moved to <a href="Richmond%2C%20Virginia">Richmond, Virginia</a>, in May of that year. In the middle of the 20th century, Montgomery was a major center of events and protests in the <a href="Civil%20Rights%20Movement">Civil Rights Movement</a>, including the <a href="Montgomery%20bus%20boycott">Montgomery bus boycott</a> and the <a href="Selma%20to%20Montgomery%20marches">Selma to Montgomery marches</a>.
In addition to housing many Alabama government agencies, Montgomery has a large <a href="Military%20of%20the%20United%20States">military</a> presence, due to <a href="Maxwell%20Air%20Force%20Base">Maxwell Air Force Base</a>; public universities <a href="Alabama%20State%20University">Alabama State University</a>, <a href="Troy%20University">Troy University</a> (Montgomery campus), and <a href="Auburn%20University%20at%20Montgomery">Auburn University at Montgomery</a>; two private post-secondary institutions, <a href="Faulkner%20University">Faulkner University</a> and <a href="Huntingdon%20College">Huntingdon College</a>; high-tech manufacturing, including <a href="Hyundai%20Motor%20Manufacturing%20Alabama">Hyundai Motor Manufacturing Alabama</a>; and many cultural attractions, such as the <a href="Alabama%20Shakespeare%20Festival">Alabama Shakespeare Festival</a> and the <a href="Montgomery%20Museum%20of%20Fine%20Arts">Montgomery Museum of Fine Arts</a>.
Two ships of the United States Navy have been named after the city, including .
Montgomery has also been recognized nationally for its downtown revitalization and new urbanism projects. It was one of the first cities in the nation to implement <a href="SmartCode">SmartCode Zoning</a>.
History.
Prior to European colonization, the east bank of the <a href="Alabama%20River">Alabama River</a> was inhabited by the <a href="Alabama%20%28people%29">Alibamu tribe</a> of <a href="Native%20Americans%20in%20the%20United%20States">Native Americans</a>. The Alibamu and the <a href="Coushatta">Coushatta</a>, who lived on the west side of the river, were descended from the <a href="Mississippian%20culture">Mississippian culture</a>. This civilization had numerous chiefdoms throughout the Midwest and South along the Mississippi and its tributaries, and had built massive <a href="earthworks%20%28archaeology%29">earthwork</a> <a href="mound">mound</a>s as part of their society about 950–1250 AD. Its largest location was at <a href="Cahokia">Cahokia</a>, in present-day <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a> east of <a href="St.%20Louis">St. Louis</a>.
The historic tribes spoke mutually intelligible <a href="Muskogean%20language">Muskogean language</a>s, which were closely related. Present-day Montgomery is built on the site of two Alibamu towns: "Ikanatchati" (Ekanchattee or Ecunchatty or Econachatee), meaning "red earth;" and "Towassa", built on a <a href="Beach%20ridge">bluff</a> called "Chunnaanaauga Chatty." The first Europeans to travel through central Alabama were <a href="Hernando%20de%20Soto">Hernando de Soto</a> and his expedition, who in 1540 recorded going through Ikanatchati and camping for one week in Towassa.
The next recorded European encounter occurred more than a century later, when an English expedition from <a href="Province%20of%20Carolina">Carolina</a> went down the Alabama River in 1697. The first permanent European settler in the Montgomery area was <a href="James%20McQueen%20%28pioneer%29">James McQueen</a>, a <a href="Scottish%20people">Scots</a> trader who settled there in 1716. He married a high-status woman in the Coushatta or Alabama tribe. Their <a href="mixed-race">mixed-race</a> children were considered Muskogean, as both tribes had a <a href="matrilineal">matrilineal</a> system of property and descent. The children were always considered born into their mother's <a href="clan">clan</a>, and gained their status from her people.
In 1785, Abraham Mordecai, a war veteran from a <a href="Sephardic%20Jewish">Sephardic Jewish</a> family of <a href="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>, Pennsylvania, established a <a href="trading%20post">trading post</a>. The Coushatta and Alabama had gradually moved south and west in the tidal plain. After the French were defeated by the British in 1763 in the <a href="French%20and%20Indian%20War">Seven Years' War</a> and ceded control of their lands, these Native American peoples moved to parts of present-day Mississippi, Louisiana, and Texas, then <a href="New%20Spain">areas of Spanish rule</a>, which they thought more favorable than British-held areas. By the time Mordecai arrived, <a href="Creek%20people">Creek</a> had migrated into and settled in the area, as they were moving away from <a href="Cherokee">Cherokee</a> and Iroquois warfare to the north. Mordecai married a Creek woman. When her people had to cede most of their lands after the 1813-14 <a href="Creek%20War">Creek War</a>, she joined them in removal to Indian Territory. Mordecai brought the first <a href="cotton%20gin">cotton gin</a> to Alabama.
The Upper Creek were able to discourage most white immigration until after the conclusion of the <a href="Creek%20War">Creek War</a>. Following their defeat by General <a href="Andrew%20Jackson">Andrew Jackson</a> in August 1814, the Creek tribes were forced to cede 23 million acres to the United States, including remaining land in today's Georgia and most of today's central and southern Alabama. In 1816, the <a href="Mississippi%20Territory">Mississippi Territory</a> (1798–1817) organized <a href="Montgomery%20County%2C%20Alabama">Montgomery County</a>. Its former Creek lands were sold off the next year at the <a href="Federal%20government%20of%20the%20United%20States">federal</a> land office in <a href="Milledgeville%2C%20Georgia">Milledgeville, Georgia</a>.
The first group of white settlers to come to the Montgomery area was headed by General <a href="John%20Scott%20%28Alabama%29">John Scott</a>. This group founded Alabama Town about downstream on the <a href="Alabama%20River">Alabama River</a> from present-day downtown Montgomery. In June 1818, county courts were moved from <a href="Fort%20Jackson%20%28Alabama%29">Fort Jackson</a> to Alabama Town. Alabama was admitted to the Union in December 1819.
Soon after, <a href="Andrew%20Dexter%20Jr.">Andrew Dexter Jr.</a> founded New Philadelphia, the present-day eastern part of downtown. He envisioned a prominent future for his town; he set aside a hilltop known as "Goat Hill" as the future site of the state capitol building. New Philadelphia soon prospered, and Scott and his associates built a new town adjacent, calling it East Alabama Town. Originally rivals, the towns merged on December 3, 1819, and were incorporated as the town of Montgomery.
 The name Montgomery came from <a href="Richard%20Montgomery">Richard Montgomery</a>, a <a href="American%20Revolutionary%20War">Revolutionary War</a> general.
Slave traders used the Alabama River to deliver slaves to planters as laborers to work the cotton. Buoyed by the revenues of the <a href="cotton">cotton</a> trade at a time of high market demand, the newly united Montgomery grew quickly. In 1822, the city was designated as the county seat. A new courthouse was built at the present location of Court Square, at the foot of Market Street (now Dexter Avenue). Court Square had one of the largest slave markets in the South. The state capital was moved from <a href="Tuscaloosa%2C%20Alabama">Tuscaloosa</a> to Montgomery, on January 28, 1846.
As state capital, Montgomery began to influence state politics, and it would also play a prominent role on the national stage. Beginning February 4, 1861, representatives from Alabama, <a href="Georgia%20%28U.S.%20state%29">Georgia</a>, Florida, <a href="Louisiana">Louisiana</a>, <a href="Mississippi">Mississippi</a>, and <a href="South%20Carolina">South Carolina</a> <a href="Montgomery%20Convention">met in Montgomery</a>, host of the "Southern Convention", to form the <a href="Confederate%20States%20of%20America">Confederate States of America</a>. Montgomery was named the first capital of the nation, and <a href="Jefferson%20Davis">Jefferson Davis</a> was inaugurated as president on the steps of the <a href="Alabama%20State%20Capitol">State Capitol</a>. (The capital was later moved to Richmond, Virginia.)
On April 12, 1865, following the <a href="Battle%20of%20Selma">Battle of Selma</a>, Major General <a href="James%20H.%20Wilson">James H. Wilson</a> captured Montgomery for the Union.
In 1886 Montgomery became the first city in the United States to install citywide electric <a href="streetcars">streetcars</a> along a system that was nicknamed the <a href="Lightning%20Route">Lightning Route</a>. Residents followed the streetcar lines to settle in new housing in what were then "suburban" locations.
 As the <a href="Reconstruction%20era">Reconstruction era</a> ended, mayor W. L. Moses asked the state legislature to <a href="gerrymander">gerrymander</a> city boundaries. It complied and removed the districts where African Americans lived, restoring white supremacy to the city's demographics and electorate. This prevented African Americans from being elected in the municipality and denied them city services. 
In the post-World War II era, returning African-American veterans were among those who became active in pushing to regain their civil rights in the South: to be allowed to vote and participate in politics, to freely use public places, to end segregation. According to the historian <a href="David%20Beito">David Beito</a> of the <a href="University%20of%20Alabama">University of Alabama</a>, African Americans in Montgomery "nurtured the <a href="Civil%20Rights%20Movement">modern civil rights movement</a>." African Americans comprised most of the customers on the city buses, but were forced to give up seats and even stand in order to make room for whites. On December 1, 1955, <a href="Rosa%20Parks">Rosa Parks</a> was arrested for refusing to give up her bus seat to a white man, sparking the <a href="Montgomery%20bus%20boycott">Montgomery bus boycott</a>. <a href="Martin%20Luther%20King%20Jr.">Martin Luther King Jr.</a>, then the pastor of <a href="Dexter%20Avenue%20Baptist%20Church">Dexter Avenue Baptist Church</a>, and <a href="E.D.%20Nixon">E.D. Nixon</a>, a local civil rights advocate, founded the <a href="Montgomery%20Improvement%20Association">Montgomery Improvement Association</a> to organize the boycott. In June 1956, the US District Court Judge <a href="Frank%20M.%20Johnson">Frank M. Johnson</a> ruled that Montgomery's bus <a href="racial%20segregation">racial segregation</a> was unconstitutional. After the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20the%20United%20States">US Supreme Court</a> upheld the ruling in November, the city desegregated the bus system, and the boycott was ended.
In separate action, integrated teams of <a href="Freedom%20Riders">Freedom Riders</a> rode South on interstate buses. In violation of federal law and the constitution, bus companies had for decades acceded to state laws and required passengers to occupy segregated seating in Southern states. Opponents of the push for integration organized mob violence at stops along the Freedom Ride. In Montgomery, there was police collaboration when a white mob attacked Freedom Riders at the <a href="Greyhound%20Bus%20Station%20%28Montgomery%2C%20Alabama%29">Greyhound Bus Station</a> in May 1961. Outraged national reaction resulted in the enforcement of desegregation of interstate public transportation.
Martin Luther King Jr. returned to Montgomery in 1965. Local civil rights leaders in <a href="Selma%2C%20Alabama">Selma</a> had been protesting <a href="Jim%20Crow%20laws">Jim Crow laws</a> and practices that raised barriers to blacks registering to vote. Following the shooting of a man after a civil rights rally, the leaders decided to <a href="Selma%20to%20Montgomery%20marches">march to Montgomery</a> to petition Governor <a href="George%20Wallace">George Wallace</a> to allow free voter registration. The violence they encountered from county and state highway police outraged the country. The federal government ordered National Guard and troops to protect the marchers. Thousands more joined the marchers on the way to Montgomery, and an estimated 25,000 marchers entered the capital to press for voting rights. These actions contributed to Congressional passage of the <a href="Voting%20Rights%20Act%20of%201965">Voting Rights Act of 1965</a>, to authorize federal supervision and enforcement of the rights of African Americans and other minorities to vote.
On February 7, 1967, a devastating fire broke out at Dale's Penthouse, a restaurant and lounge on the top floor of the Walter Bragg Smith apartment building (now called Capital Towers) at 7 Clayton Street downtown. Twenty-six people died.
In recent years, Montgomery has grown and diversified its economy. Active in downtown revitalization, the city adopted a master plan in 2007; it includes the revitalization of Court Square and the riverfront, renewing the city's connection to the river. Many other projects under construction include the revitalization of Historic Dexter Avenue, pedestrian and infrastructure improvements along the <a href="Selma%20to%20Montgomery%20National%20Historic%20Trail">Selma to Montgomery National Historic Trail</a>, and the construction of a new environmental park on West Fairview Avenue.
Geography.
Montgomery is located at .
According to the <a href="United%20States%20Census%20Bureau">U.S. Census Bureau</a>, the city has a total area of , of which is land and (0.52%) is water. The city is built over rolling terrain at an elevation of about above sea level.
Cityscape.
Downtown Montgomery lies along the southern bank of the <a href="Alabama%20River">Alabama River</a>, about downstream from the confluence of the <a href="Coosa%20River">Coosa</a> and <a href="Tallapoosa%20River">Tallapoosa</a> rivers. The most prominent feature of Montgomery's skyline is the , RSA Tower, built in 1996 by the <a href="Retirement%20Systems%20of%20Alabama">Retirement Systems of Alabama</a>. Other prominent buildings include 60 Commerce Street, 8 Commerce Street, and the <a href="RSA%20Dexter%20Avenue%20Building">RSA Dexter Avenue Building</a>. Downtown also contains many state and local government buildings, including the <a href="Alabama%20State%20Capitol">Alabama State Capitol</a>. The Capitol is located atop a hill at one end of Dexter Avenue, along which also lies the <a href="Dexter%20Avenue%20Baptist%20Church">Dexter Avenue Baptist Church</a>, where <a href="Martin%20Luther%20King%20Jr.">Martin Luther King Jr.</a> was pastor. Both the Capitol and Dexter Baptist Church are recognized as <a href="National%20Historic%20Landmark">National Historic Landmark</a>s by the <a href="U.S.%20Department%20of%20the%20Interior">U.S. Department of the Interior</a>. Other notable buildings include RSA Dexter Avenue, RSA Headquarters, Alabama Center for Commerce, RSA Union, and the Renaissance Hotel and Spa.
One block south of the Capitol is the <a href="First%20White%20House%20of%20the%20Confederacy">First White House of the Confederacy</a>, the 1835 Italianate-style house in which President Jefferson Davis and family lived while the Confederate capital was in Montgomery. Montgomery's third National Historic Landmark is <a href="Union%20Station%20%28Montgomery%29">Union Station</a>. Passenger train service to Montgomery ceased in 1989. Today Union Station is part of the Riverfront Park development, which includes an amphitheater, a <a href="Paddle%20steamer">riverboat</a> dock, a river walk, and <a href="Montgomery%20Riverwalk%20Stadium">Riverwalk Stadium</a>.
Three blocks east of the Convention Center, <a href="Old%20Alabama%20Town">Old Alabama Town</a> showcases more than 50 restored buildings from the 19th century. The Riverwalk is part of a larger plan to revitalize the downtown area and connect it to the waterfront. The plan includes <a href="urban%20forestry">urban forestry</a>, infill development, and façade renovation to encourage business and residential growth. A The Convention Center, completed in 2007, has encouraged growth and activity in the downtown area, and attracted more high-end retail and restaurants.
Other downtown developments include historic Dexter Avenue, which will be the center of a Market District. A $6 million streetscape project is improving its design. Maxwell Boulevard is home to the newly built <a href="Wright%20Brothers">Wright Brothers</a> Park. High-end apartments are planned for this area. The <a href="Bell%20Building%20%28Montgomery%2C%20Alabama%29">Bell Building</a>, located across from the Rosa Parks Library and Museum, is being redeveloped for mixed-use retail and residential space.
The <a href="National%20Memorial%20for%20Peace%20and%20Justice">National Memorial for Peace and Justice</a> opened in downtown Montgomery on April 26, 2018. Founded by the <a href="Equal%20Justice%20Initiative">Equal Justice Initiative</a>, it acknowledges the historic past of racial terrorism and lynching in America.
South of downtown, across <a href="Interstate%2085">Interstate 85</a>, lies <a href="Alabama%20State%20University">Alabama State University</a>. ASU's campus was built in <a href="Colonial%20Revival%20architecture">Colonial Revival</a> architectural style from 1906 until the beginning of World War II. Surrounding ASU are the <a href="Garden%20District%20%28Montgomery%2C%20Alabama%29">Garden District</a> and <a href="Cloverdale%20Historic%20District">Cloverdale Historic District</a>. Houses in these areas date from around 1875 until 1949, and are in <a href="Victorian%20architecture">Late Victorian</a> and <a href="Gothic%20Revival%20architecture">Gothic Revival</a> styles. <a href="Huntingdon%20College">Huntingdon College</a> is on the southwestern edge of Cloverdale. The campus was built in the 1900s in <a href="Tudorbethan%20architecture">Tudor Revival</a> and Gothic Revival styles. ASU, the Garden District, Cloverdale, and Huntingdon are all listed on the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places">National Register of Historic Places</a> as <a href="historic%20district%20%28United%20States%29">historic district</a>s.
Montgomery's east side is the fastest-growing part of the city. Development of the Dalraida neighborhood, along Atlanta Highway, began in 1909, when developers Cook and Laurie bought land from the Ware plantation. A Scotsman, Georgie Laurie named the area for <a href="D%C3%A1l%20Riata">Dál Riata</a>, a 6th-7th century Gaelic overkingdom; a subsequent misspelling in an advertisement led to the current spelling. The first lots were sold in 1914. The city's two largest shopping malls (<a href="Eastdale%20Mall">Eastdale Mall</a> and <a href="The%20Shoppes%20at%20Eastchase">The Shoppes at Eastchase</a>), as well as many <a href="big-box%20stores">big-box stores</a> and residential developments, are on the east side.
The area is also home of the <a href="Wynton%20M.%20Blount%20Cultural%20Park">Wynton M. Blount Cultural Park</a>. This park contains the <a href="Alabama%20Shakespeare%20Festival">Alabama Shakespeare Festival</a> and <a href="Montgomery%20Museum%20of%20Fine%20Arts">Montgomery Museum of Fine Arts</a>.
Revitalization.
Montgomery has been recognized nationally for its continuing downtown revitalization. In the early 2000s, the city constructed the <a href="Montgomery%20Biscuits">Montgomery Biscuits</a> minor league baseball stadium and Riverfront Park. Following those developments, hundreds of millions of dollars have been invested by private companies that have adapted old warehouses and office buildings into loft apartments, restaurants, retail, hotels, and businesses. The demand for downtown living space has risen, as people want to have walkable, lively neighborhoods. More than 500 apartment units are under construction, including The Heights on Maxwell Boulevard, The Market District on Dexter Avenue, the Kress Building on Dexter Avenue, The <a href="Bell%20Building%20%28Montgomery%2C%20Alabama%29">Bell Building</a> on Montgomery Street, and a new complex by the convention center.
Climate.
Montgomery has a <a href="humid%20subtropical%20climate">humid subtropical climate</a> (<a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen</a> "Cfa"), with short, mild winters, warm springs and autumns, and long, hot, humid summers. The daily average temperature in January is , and there are 3.4 days of sub lows; and below is extremely rare. The daily average in July is , with highs exceeding on 86 days per year and on 3.9. Summer afternoon heat indices, much more often than the actual air temperature, are frequently at or above 100 °F. The <a href="diurnal%20temperature%20variation">diurnal temperature variation</a> tends to be large in spring and autumn. Rainfall is well-distributed throughout the year, though February, March and July are the wettest months, while October is significantly the driest month. Snowfall occurs only during some winters, and even then is usually light. Substantial snowstorms are rare, but do occur approximately once every 10 years. Extremes range from on <a href="Great%20Blizzard%20of%201899">February 13, 1899</a> to on July 7, 1881.
Thunderstorms bring much of Montgomery's rainfall. These are common during the summer months but occur throughout the year. Severe thunderstorms – producing large hail and damaging winds in addition to the usual hazards of lightning and heavy rain – can occasionally occur, particularly during the spring. Severe storms also bring a risk of <a href="tornadoes">tornadoes</a>. Sometimes, tropical disturbances – some of which strike the Gulf Coast as hurricanes before losing intensity as they move inland – can bring very heavy rains.
Demographics.
2020 census.
As of the <a href="2020%20United%20States%20census">2020 United States census</a>, there were 200,603 people, 78,225 households, and 45,031 families residing in the city.
2010 census.
As of the <a href="2010%20United%20States%20Census">2010 census</a>, the population of the city was 205,764. There were 81,486 households, out of which 29% had children under the age of 18 living with them. The racial makeup of the city was 37.3% <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">White</a>, 56.6% <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">Black</a>, 2.2% <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">Asian</a>, 0.2% <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">Native American</a>, 0.1% <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">Pacific Islander</a>, 2.2% from <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">other races</a>, and 1.3% from two or more races. 3.9% of the population were <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">Hispanic</a> or <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">Latino</a> of any race. <a href="Non-Hispanic%20Whites">Non-Hispanic Whites</a> were 36.1% of the population in 2010, down from 66% in 1970. The population density varies in different parts of the city; East Montgomery (Taylor Rd and East), the non-Hispanic White population is 74.5%, 8.3% African American, Latino 3.2%, other non-white races carry 2.7% of the population.
The city population was spread out, with 24.9% under the age of 18, 11.7% from 18 to 24, 27.3% from 25 to 44, 24.2% from 45 to 64, and 11.8% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 34 years. For every 100 females, there were 88.6 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 84.5 males. The median income for a household in the city was $41,380, and the median income for a family was $53,125. Males had a median income of $40,255 versus $33,552 for females. The per capita income for the city was $23,139. About 18.2% of families and 21.6% of the population were below the poverty line, including 34.8% of those under age 18 and 8.4% of those age 65 or over.
Economy.
Montgomery's central location in Alabama's <a href="Black%20Belt%20%28region%20of%20Alabama%29">Black Belt</a> has long made it a processing hub for commodity crops such as cotton, peanuts, and <a href="soybean">soybean</a>s. In 1840 <a href="Montgomery%20County%2C%20Alabama">Montgomery County</a> led the state in cotton production, and by 1911, the city processed 160,000–200,000 bales of cotton annually. Montgomery has also had large metal fabrication and lumber production sectors.
Due to its location along the <a href="Alabama%20River">Alabama River</a> and extensive rail connections, Montgomery has been and continues to be a regional distribution hub for a wide range of industries. Since the late 20th century, it has diversified its economy, achieving increased employment in sectors such as healthcare, business, government, and manufacturing. Today, the city's Gross Metropolitan Product is $12.15 billion, representing 8.7% of the gross state product of Alabama.
According to <a href="Bureau%20of%20Labor%20Statistics">Bureau of Labor Statistics</a> data from October 2008, the largest sectors of non-agricultural employment were: Government, 24.3%; Trade, Transportation, and Utilities, 17.3% (including 11.0% in retail trade); Professional and Business Services, 11.9%; Manufacturing, 10.9%; Education and Health Services, 10.0% (including 8.5% in Health Care & Social Assistance); Leisure and Hospitality, 9.2%; Financial Activities, 6.0%, Natural Resources, Mining and Construction, 5.1%; Information, 1.4%; and Other services 4.0%. Unemployment for the same period was 5.7%, 2.5% higher than October 2007. The city also draws in workers from the surrounding area; Montgomery's daytime population rises 17.4% to 239,101.
As of January 2011, Montgomery's largest employers were <a href="Maxwell%20Air%20Force%20Base">Maxwell-Gunter Air Force Base</a> (12,280 employees), the <a href="Government%20of%20Alabama">state of Alabama</a> (9,500), <a href="Montgomery%20Public%20Schools">Montgomery Public Schools</a> (4,524), Baptist Health (4,300), <a href="Hyundai%20Motor%20Manufacturing%20Alabama">Hyundai Motor Manufacturing Alabama</a> (3,000), Alfa Insurance (2,568), the City of Montgomery (2,500), Jackson Hospital & Clinic (1,300), <a href="Rheem%20Manufacturing%20Company">Rheem</a> Water Heaters (1,147), and <a href="Regions%20Financial%20Corporation">Regions</a> (977).
According to <a href="Pennsylvania%20State%20University">Pennsylvania State University</a>'s Living Wage Calculator, the <a href="living%20wage">living wage</a> for the city is US$8.02 per hour (or $16,691 per year) for an individual and $25.80 per hour ($53,662 per year) for a family of four. These are slightly higher than the state averages of $7.45 per hour for an individual and $25.36 for a family of four.
Health care.
Montgomery serves as a hub for healthcare in the central Alabama and <a href="Black%20Belt%20%28region%20of%20Alabama%29">Black Belt</a> region. Hospitals located in the city include Baptist Medical Center South on South East Boulevard, Baptist Medical Center East next to the campus of <a href="Auburn%20University%20Montgomery">Auburn University Montgomery</a> on Taylor Road, and Jackson Hospital, which is located next to Oak Park off interstate 85. Montgomery is also home to two medical school campuses: Baptist Medical Center South (run by <a href="University%20of%20Alabama%20at%20Birmingham">University of Alabama at Birmingham</a>) and Jackson Hospital (run by Alabama Medical Education Consortium).
Law and government.
Montgomery operates under a <a href="Mayor%E2%80%93council%20government">Mayor–council government</a> system. The mayor and council members are elected to four-year terms. The current mayor is <a href="Steven%20Reed%20%28mayor%29">Steven Reed</a>, who was elected as the city's first African-American mayor in a runoff election which was held on October 8, 2019. The city is served by a nine-member city council, elected from nine single-member districts of equal size population.
As the <a href="county%20seat">seat</a> of <a href="Montgomery%20County%2C%20Alabama">Montgomery County</a>, the city is the location of county courts and the county commission, elected separately. Montgomery is the capital of Alabama, and hosts numerous <a href="Government%20of%20Alabama">state government</a> offices, including the office of the <a href="Governor%20of%20Alabama">Governor</a>, the <a href="Alabama%20Legislature">Alabama Legislature</a>, and the <a href="Alabama%20Supreme%20Court">Alabama Supreme Court</a>.
At the federal level, Montgomery is part of Alabama's <a href="Alabama%27s%202nd%20congressional%20district">2nd</a>, <a href="Alabama%27s%207th%20congressional%20district">7th</a>, and <a href="Alabama%27s%203rd%20congressional%20district">3rd Congressional district</a>, currently represented by <a href="Barry%20Moore%20%28Alabama%20politician%29">Barry Moore</a>, <a href="Terri%20Sewell">Terri Sewell</a>, and <a href="Mike%20D.%20Rogers">Mike Rogers</a>, respectively. The 7th represents most of Western Montgomery, the 2nd Southern and Northern Montgomery, and the 3rd Eastern Montgomery.
Crime.
Montgomery's crime rates compare favorably to other large cities in the state. In 2009 Montgomery's violent crime rate was 429.4 per 100,000, well below that of Birmingham, Huntsville, and Mobile, below the state average, and similar to the national average. For property crimes, Montgomery's average is similar to Alabama's other large cities, but higher than the overall state and national averages.
Recreation.
Montgomery has more than 1,600 acres of parkland, which are maintained and operated by the City of Montgomery Parks and Recreation Department. The department also operates 24 community centers, a skate park, two golf courses (Lagoon Park and Gateway Park), Cramton Bowl Stadium and Multiplex, two tennis centers (Lagoon Park and O'Conner), 65 playgrounds, 90 baseball/softball fields, 24 soccer fields including the <a href="Emory%20Folmar">Emory Folmar</a> Soccer Facility, and one riverboat. An environmental park is under construction along West Fairview Avenue close to Interstate 65.
Culture.
Montgomery has one of the biggest arts scenes of any mid-sized city in America. The <a href="Winton%20M.%20Blount%20Cultural%20Park">Winton M. Blount Cultural Park</a> (named for <a href="Winton%20M.%20Blount">Winton M. Blount</a>) in east Montgomery is home to the <a href="Montgomery%20Museum%20of%20Fine%20Arts">Montgomery Museum of Fine Arts</a>. The museum's permanent collections include American art and sculpture, <a href="Southern%20United%20States">Southern</a> art, master prints from European masters, and collections of porcelain and glass works. The Society of Arts and Crafts operates a co-op gallery for local artists.
<a href="Montgomery%20Zoo">Montgomery Zoo</a> holds more than 500 animals, from five continents, in of barrier-free habitats. The <a href="Hank%20Williams%20Museum">Hank Williams Museum</a> contains one of the largest collections of Williams memorabilia in the world. The Museum of Alabama serves as the official state history museum and is located in the <a href="Alabama%20Department%20of%20Archives%20and%20History">Alabama Department of Archives and History</a> building downtown. This museum was renovated and expanded in 2013 in a $10 million project that includes technological upgrades and many new exhibits and displays. The <a href="W.%20A.%20Gayle%20Planetarium">W. A. Gayle Planetarium</a>, operated by <a href="Troy%20University">Troy University</a>, is one of the largest in the southeast United States and offers tours of the night sky and shows about current topics in <a href="astronomy">astronomy</a>. The <a href="planetarium">planetarium</a> was upgraded to a full-dome digital projector in 2014.
Blount Park also contains the <a href="Alabama%20Shakespeare%20Festival">Alabama Shakespeare Festival</a>'s Carolyn Blount Theatre. The Shakespeare Festival presents year-round performances of both classic plays and performances of local interest, in addition to works of <a href="William%20Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a>. The 1200-seat <a href="Davis%20Theatre%20for%20the%20Performing%20Arts">Davis Theatre for the Performing Arts</a>, on the <a href="Troy%20University%20at%20Montgomery">Troy University at Montgomery</a> campus, opened in 1930 and was renovated in 1983. It houses the <a href="Montgomery%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Montgomery Symphony Orchestra</a>, <a href="Alabama%20Dance%20Theatre">Alabama Dance Theatre</a> and <a href="Montgomery%20Ballet">Montgomery Ballet</a>, as well as other theatrical productions. The Symphony has been performing in Montgomery since 1979. The Capri Theatre in <a href="Cloverdale%2C%20Montgomery">Cloverdale</a> was built in 1941, and today shows <a href="independent%20film">independent film</a>s. The 1800-seat state-of-the-art Montgomery Performing Arts Center opened inside the newly renovated convention center downtown in 2007. It hosts a range of performances, from Broadway plays to concerts, and performers such as <a href="BB%20King">BB King</a>, <a href="Gregg%20Allman">Gregg Allman</a>, and <a href="Merle%20Haggard">Merle Haggard</a>.
Numerous musical performers have roots in Montgomery: Toni Tennille of the duo The Captain and Tennille, jazz singer and pianist <a href="Nat%20King%20Cole">Nat King Cole</a>, country singer <a href="Hank%20Williams">Hank Williams</a>, blues singer <a href="Big%20Mama%20Thornton">Big Mama Thornton</a>, <a href="Melvin%20Franklin">Melvin Franklin</a> of <a href="The%20Temptations">The Temptations</a>, and guitarist <a href="Tommy%20Shaw">Tommy Shaw</a> of <a href="Styx%20%28band%29">Styx</a>.
Author and artist <a href="Zelda%20Sayre">Zelda Sayre</a> was born in Montgomery. In 1918, she met <a href="F.%20Scott%20Fitzgerald">F. Scott Fitzgerald</a>, then a young soldier stationed at an Army post nearby. The house where they lived when first married is today operated as the <a href="F.%20Scott%20and%20Zelda%20Fitzgerald%20Museum">F. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald Museum</a>. Poet <a href="Sidney%20Lanier">Sidney Lanier</a> lived in Montgomery and <a href="Prattville%2C%20Alabama">Prattville</a> immediately after the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">Civil War</a>, while writing his novel "Tiger Lilies."
In addition to those notable earlier musicians, some of the rock bands from Montgomery have achieved national success since the late 20th century. Locals artists <a href="Trust%20Company%20%28band%29">Trust Company</a> were signed to <a href="Geffen%20Records">Geffen Records</a> in 2002. <a href="Hot%20Rod%20Circuit">Hot Rod Circuit</a> formed in Montgomery in 1997 under the name Antidote, but achieved success with <a href="Vagrant%20Records">Vagrant Records</a> after moving to <a href="Connecticut">Connecticut</a>.
Sports.
Montgomery is home of the <a href="Montgomery%20Biscuits">Montgomery Biscuits</a> baseball team. The Biscuits play in the <a href="Double-A%20%28baseball%29">Class AA</a> <a href="Southern%20League%20%281964%E2%80%932020%29">Southern League</a>. They are affiliated with the <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Rays">Tampa Bay Rays</a>, and play at <a href="Montgomery%20Riverwalk%20Stadium">Montgomery Riverwalk Stadium</a>. Riverwalk Stadium hosted the <a href="NCAA%20Division%20II">NCAA Division II</a> National Baseball Championship from 2004 until 2007. The championship had previously been played at <a href="Paterson%20Field">Paterson Field</a> in Montgomery from 1985 until 2003. Riverwalk Stadium has also been host to two Southern League All-Star games in 2006 and 2015.
The <a href="Yokohama%20Tire%20LPGA%20Classic">Yokohama Tire LPGA Classic</a> women's golf event is held at the <a href="Robert%20Trent%20Jones%20Golf%20Trail">Robert Trent Jones Golf Trail</a> at Capitol Hill in nearby <a href="Prattville%2C%20Alabama">Prattville</a>. <a href="Garrett%20Coliseum">Garrett Coliseum</a> was the home of the now-defunct <a href="Montgomery%20Bears">Montgomery Bears</a> <a href="Indoor%20American%20football">indoor football</a> team.
Montgomery is also the site of sporting events hosted by the area's colleges and universities. The <a href="Alabama%20State%20University">Alabama State University</a> Hornets play in <a href="NCAA%20Division%20I">NCAA Division I</a> competition in the <a href="Southwestern%20Athletic%20Conference">Southwestern Athletic Conference</a> (SWAC). The <a href="American%20football">football</a> team plays at Hornet Stadium, the basketball teams play at the Dunn-Oliver Acadome, and the baseball team plays at the ASU Baseball Complex, which recently opened on March 26, 2010. <a href="Auburn%20University%20at%20Montgomery">Auburn University at Montgomery</a> also fields teams in <a href="National%20Association%20of%20Intercollegiate%20Athletics">NAIA</a> competition. <a href="Huntingdon%20College">Huntingdon College</a> participates at the NCAA Division III level and <a href="Faulkner%20University">Faulkner University</a> is a member of the NAIA and is a nearby rival of Auburn University at Montgomery. The <a href="Blue%E2%80%93Gray%20Football%20Classic">Blue–Gray Football Classic</a> was an annual college football <a href="all-star%20game">all-star game</a> held from 1938 until 2001. In 2009, the city played host to the first annual Historical Black College and University (HBCU) All-Star Football Bowl played at Cramton Bowl. Beginning in 2014 Montgomery will be host to the <a href="Southern%20Intercollegiate%20Athletic%20Conference">Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Conference</a> football championship; this will take place in Cramton Bowl. Starting in December 2014, Montgomery will host the <a href="Camellia%20Bowl%20%282014%E2%80%93present%29">Camellia Bowl</a> at the Cramton Bowl as part of the annual college football <a href="bowl%20game">bowl game</a> schedule. Montgomery annually hosts the Max Capital City Classic inside Riverwalk Stadium which is a baseball game between big rivals <a href="Auburn%20University">Auburn University</a> and <a href="The%20University%20of%20Alabama">The University of Alabama</a>.
Several successful professional athletes hail from Montgomery, including <a href="Pro%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Pro Football Hall of Fame</a>r <a href="Bart%20Starr">Bart Starr</a> and <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201984%20Summer%20Olympics">two-time Olympic gold medalist</a> in track and field <a href="Alonzo%20Babers">Alonzo Babers</a>.
The city was host to the 2015 World Firefighter Combat Challenge. It aired on <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a> in October of that year.
In 2016 Montgomery was also the host city to the National Horseshoe Pitchers Association World Horseshoe Tournament.
Civic organizations.
Montgomery has many active governmental and nonprofit civic organizations. City funded organizations include the Montgomery Clean City Commission (a Keep America Beautiful Affiliate) which works to promote cleanliness and environmental awareness. BONDS (Building Our Neighborhoods for Development and Success) which works to engage citizens about city/nonprofit programs, coordinates/assists neighborhood associations, and works to promote neighborhood and civic pride amongst Montgomery residents.
A number of organizations are focused on diversity relations and the city's rich <a href="civil%20rights">civil rights</a> history. Leadership Montgomery provides citizenship training. Bridge Builders Alabama works with high school youth to promote diversity and civic engagement. The group <a href="One%20Montgomery">One Montgomery</a> was founded in 1983 and is a forum for networking of a diverse group of citizens active in civic affairs. Montgomery is also home to <a href="The%20Legacy%20Museum">The Legacy Museum</a>, <a href="Civil%20Rights%20Memorial">Civil Rights Memorial</a>, <a href="The%20National%20Memorial%20for%20Peace%20and%20Justice">The National Memorial for Peace and Justice</a>, Freedom Rides Museum, the National Center for the Study of Civil Rights and African-American Culture, and the <a href="Rosa%20Parks%20Museum">Rosa Parks Library and Museum</a>.
Education.
The city of Montgomery and Montgomery County are served by the <a href="Montgomery%20Public%20Schools">Montgomery Public Schools</a> system. As of 2007, there were 32,520 students enrolled in the system, and 2,382 teachers employed. The system manages 32 elementary schools, 10 middle schools, and 5 high schools as well as 9 <a href="magnet%20school">magnet school</a>s, 1 <a href="alternative%20school">alternative school</a>, and 2 <a href="special%20education">special education</a> centers. Montgomery is one of the only cities in Alabama to host three public schools with <a href="International%20Baccalaureate">International Baccalaureate</a> programs. In 2007, Forest Avenue Academic Magnet Elementary School and in 2015, Bear Exploration Center were named a <a href="National%20Blue%20Ribbon%20School">National Blue Ribbon School</a>. In 2018, <a href="Loveless%20Academic%20Magnet%20Program%20%28LAMP%29">LAMP</a> High School was named the No. 13 <a href="magnet%20school">magnet school</a> in the United States and No. 1 public high school in the state of Alabama on "<a href="U.S.%20News%20%26amp%3B%20World%20Report">U.S. News & World Report</a>"'s list. Three other Montgomery Public Schools high schools were also on the list, the most of any public school system in the state (BTW Magnet, <a href="Brewbaker%20Technology%20Magnet%20High%20School">Brewbaker Technology Magnet</a>, and Carver High School). Montgomery is also home to 28 private schools.
The <a href="Montgomery%20City-County%20Public%20Library">Montgomery City-County Public Library</a> operates eleven public libraries in locations throughout the city and county.
The city is home to Alabama's oldest law library, the Supreme Court and State Law Library, founded in 1828. Located in the Heflin-Torbert Judicial Building, the Law Library owns a rare book collection containing works printed as early as 1605.
Montgomery has been the home of <a href="Alabama%20State%20University">Alabama State University</a>, a <a href="Historically%20black%20colleges%20and%20universities">historically black university</a>, since the Lincoln Normal University for Teachers relocated from <a href="Marion%2C%20Alabama">Marion</a> in 1887. Today, ASU is the second largest HBCU in Alabama enrolling nearly 5,000 students from 42 U.S. states and 7 countries. The public <a href="Troy%20University%20at%20Montgomery">Troy University</a> maintains a 3,000 student population campus in downtown Montgomery that houses the <a href="Rosa%20Parks">Rosa Parks</a> Library and Museum. Another public institution, <a href="Auburn%20University%20at%20Montgomery">Auburn University at Montgomery</a>, with an enrollment of nearly 5,000 overwhelmingly from the <a href="Montgomery%20metropolitan%20area">Montgomery area</a>, is in the eastern part of the city. Montgomery's Baptist Medical Center South also hosts a branch of the <a href="University%20of%20Alabama%20Birmingham">University of Alabama Birmingham</a> medical school on its campus on the Eastern Boulevard.
Montgomery also is home to several private colleges: <a href="Faulkner%20University">Faulkner University</a>, which has an enrollment of 3,500, is a <a href="Church%20of%20Christ">Church of Christ</a>-affiliated school which is home to the <a href="Thomas%20Goode%20Jones%20School%20of%20Law">Thomas Goode Jones School of Law</a>. <a href="Huntingdon%20College">Huntingdon College</a>, which has a current student population of 1,000 and is affiliated with the <a href="United%20Methodist%20Church">United Methodist Church</a>; <a href="Virginia%20College">Virginia College</a> and <a href="Amridge%20University">Amridge University</a>.
Several two-year colleges have campuses in Montgomery, including <a href="H.%20Councill%20Trenholm%20State%20Technical%20College">H. Councill Trenholm State Technical College</a>
<a href="Maxwell%20Air%20Force%20Base">Maxwell Air Force Base</a> is the headquarters for <a href="Air%20University%20%28United%20States%29">Air University</a>, the <a href="United%20States%20Air%20Force">United States Air Force</a>'s center for professional military education. Branches of Air University based in Montgomery include the <a href="Squadron%20Officer%20School">Squadron Officer School</a>, the <a href="Air%20Command%20and%20Staff%20College">Air Command and Staff College</a>, the <a href="Air%20War%20College">Air War College</a>, and the <a href="Community%20College%20of%20the%20Air%20Force">Community College of the Air Force</a>.
Media.
The morning newspaper, the "<a href="Montgomery%20Advertiser">Montgomery Advertiser</a>", began publication as "The Planter's Gazette" in 1829. It is the principal newspaper of central Alabama and is affiliated with the <a href="Gannett%20Corporation">Gannett Corporation</a>. In 1970, then publisher <a href="Harold%20E.%20Martin">Harold E. Martin</a> won the <a href="Pulitzer%20Prize">Pulitzer Prize</a> for special reporting while at the "Advertiser". The "Alabama Journal" was a local afternoon paper from 1899 until April 16, 1993, when it published its last issue before merging with the morning Advertiser.
Montgomery is served by seven local television stations: <a href="WNCF">WNCF 32</a> (<a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>), <a href="WSFA">WSFA 12</a> (<a href="NBC">NBC</a>), <a href="WCOV-TV">WCOV 20</a> (<a href="Fox%20Broadcasting%20Company">Fox</a>), <a href="WBMM">WBMM 22</a> (<a href="The%20CW%20Television%20Network">CW</a>), <a href="WAIQ">WAIQ 26</a> (<a href="PBS">PBS</a>), <a href="WMCF-TV">WMCF-TV 45</a> (<a href="Trinity%20Broadcasting%20Network">TBN</a>), <a href="WFRZ-LD">WFRZ-LD 33</a> (Religious and Educational). In addition, <a href="WAKA">WAKA 8</a> (<a href="CBS">CBS</a>), licensed to Selma but operating out of Montgomery, and <a href="WBIH">WBIH 29</a> (independent) located in <a href="Selma%2C%20Alabama">Selma</a>, and <a href="WIYC">WIYC 67</a> (<a href="American%20Music%20Video%20Network">AMV</a>) is licensed to <a href="Troy%2C%20Alabama">Troy</a>. Montgomery is part of the <a href="media%20market">(DMA)</a>, which is ranked 118th nationally by <a href="Nielsen%20Media%20Research">Nielsen Media Research</a>. <a href="Charter%20Communications">Charter Communications</a> and <a href="Knology">Knology</a> provide cable television service. <a href="DirecTV">DirecTV</a> and <a href="Dish%20Network">Dish Network</a> provide <a href="direct%20broadcast%20satellite">direct broadcast satellite</a> television including both local and national channels to area residents.
The Montgomery area is served by eight <a href="AM%20broadcasting">AM</a> radio stations: <a href="WMSP">WMSP</a>, <a href="WMGY">WMGY</a>, <a href="WZKD">WZKD</a>, <a href="WTBF%20%28AM%29">WTBF</a>, <a href="WGMP">WGMP</a>, <a href="WAPZ">WAPZ</a>, <a href="WLWI%20%28AM%29">WLWI</a>, and <a href="WXVI">WXVI</a>; and nineteen <a href="FM%20broadcasting">FM</a> stations: <a href="WJSP-FM">WJSP</a>, <a href="WAPR">WAPR</a>, <a href="WELL-FM">WELL</a>, <a href="WLBF">WLBF</a>, <a href="Troy%20University%20Public%20Radio">WTSU</a>, <a href="WVAS">WVAS</a>, <a href="WLWI-FM">WLWI</a>, <a href="WXFX">WXFX</a>, <a href="WQKS-FM">WQKS</a>, <a href="WWMG">WWMG</a>, <a href="WVRV">WVRV</a>, <a href="WJWZ">WJWZ</a>, <a href="WBAM-FM">WBAM</a>, <a href="WALX">WALX</a>, <a href="WHHY-FM">WHHY</a>, <a href="WMXS">WMXS</a>, <a href="WHLW">WHLW</a>, <a href="WZHT">WZHT</a>, and <a href="WMRK-FM">WMRK</a>. Montgomery is ranked 150th largest by <a href="Arbitron">Arbitron</a>.
NOAA Weather Radio station <a href="KIH55">KIH55</a> broadcasts weather and hazard information for Montgomery and vicinity.
Transportation.
Two interstate highways run through Montgomery. <a href="Interstate%2065">Interstate 65</a> is the primary north–south freeway through the city leading between <a href="Birmingham%2C%20Alabama">Birmingham</a> and <a href="Huntsville%2C%20Alabama">Huntsville</a> to the north and <a href="Mobile%2C%20Alabama">Mobile</a> to the south. Montgomery is the southern terminus of <a href="Interstate%2085">Interstate 85</a>, another north–south freeway (though running east–west in the city), which leads northeast to <a href="Atlanta">Atlanta</a>. The major surface street thoroughfare is a loop consisting of <a href="State%20Route%20152%20%28Alabama%29">State Route 152</a> in the north, <a href="U.S.%20Highway%20231">U.S. Highway 231</a> and <a href="U.S.%20Highway%2080">U.S. Highway 80</a> in the east, <a href="U.S.%20Highway%2082">U.S. Highway 82</a> in the south, and <a href="U.S.%20Route%2031%20in%20Alabama">U.S. Highway 31</a> along the west of the city. The <a href="Alabama%20Department%20of%20Transportation">Alabama Department of Transportation</a> is planning the Outer Montgomery Loop to ease traffic congestion in the city. It is planned to connect <a href="Interstate%2085">Interstate 85</a> near <a href="Mount%20Meigs%2C%20Alabama">Mt. Meigs</a> to <a href="U.S.%20Highway%2080">U.S. Highway 80</a> southwest of the city. Upon completion of the loop, it will carry the I-85 designation while the original I-85 into the city center will be redesignated <a href="Interstate%20685">I-685</a>.
<a href="Montgomery%20Area%20Transit%20System">Montgomery Area Transit System</a> (The M) provides public transportation with buses serving the city. The system has 32 buses providing an average of 4500 passenger trips daily. The M's ridership has shown steady growth since the system was revamped in 2000; the system served over 1 million passenger trips in 2007. <a href="Greyhound%20Lines">Greyhound Lines</a> operates a terminal in Montgomery for intercity bus travel; <a href="Megabus%20%28North%20America%29">Megabus (North America)</a> also operates in the city out of the downtown Intermodal Transit Facility.
<a href="Montgomery%20Regional%20Airport">Montgomery Regional Airport</a>, also known as Dannelly Field, is the major airport serving Montgomery. It serves primarily as an <a href="Air%20National%20Guard">Air National Guard</a> base and for general aviation, but commercial airlines fly to regional connections to <a href="Hartsfield-Jackson%20Atlanta%20International%20Airport">Atlanta</a>, <a href="Dallas/Fort%20Worth%20International%20Airport">Dallas–Fort Worth</a> and <a href="Charlotte/Douglas%20International%20Airport">Charlotte</a>.
Passenger rail service to Montgomery was enhanced in 1898 with the opening of <a href="Union%20Station%20%28Montgomery%29">Union Station</a>. Service continued until 1979, when <a href="Amtrak">Amtrak</a> terminated its <a href="Floridian%20%28Amtrak%29">Floridian</a> route. Amtrak returned from 1989 until 1995 with the <a href="Gulf%20Breeze%20%28Amtrak%29">Gulf Breeze</a>, an extension of the <a href="Crescent%20%28Amtrak%29">Crescent</a> line.
According to the 2016 <a href="American%20Community%20Survey">American Community Survey</a>, 84.3% of working city of Montgomery residents commuted by driving alone, 8.8% carpooled, 0.4% used public transportation, and 0.6% walked. About 3.5% used all other forms of transportation, including taxicab, motorcycle, and bicycle. About 5.9% of working city of Montgomery residents worked at home. Despite the high level of commuting by automobile, 8.5% of city of Montgomery households were without a car in 2015, which increased to 11% in 2016. The national average was 8.7 percent in 2016. Montgomery averaged 1.62 cars per household in 2016, compared to a national average of 1.8 per household.
Sister city.
Montgomery has one <a href="sister%20city">sister city</a>:
